38853967.review: This is a spectactularly good adventure game that i wish i had played earlier. The story zaps you into some magical world that is currently suffering under a regime that worships at the altars of austerity and trickle-down economics. You wander about talking to interesting characters as you help them out of the mess. What makes this game great is not the puzzles (they are essentially all just fetch quests), but the excellent dialog and description text. There is lots to click on, and everything is just the right balance of absurd and profound and laugh-out-loud funny. It might not be to everyone's tastes, but if you're into politics and surrealism and oddball comedy this is definitely worth the time.

37756457.review:
I did not truly know what to expect with The Sea Will Claim Everything, but I was very happily surprised with what it was!

The game is a unique point-and-click adventure story. The graphics are mostly 2D drawings that do not move, though there are some places where this changes quite a bit. Many things on the screen do not drastically stand out from other objects. This is somewhat ironic, because the game is the absolute opposite of typical point-and-click games where the interactive items stand out.

In fact, nearly everything on the screen can be clicked to generate many different outcomes. Some are traditional, such as text descriptions of items or dialogue with characters. While others may cause weird events to occur, generate sounds or jokes, affect your UI, and so on. The game tends to break the 4th wall quite a lot in its sense of humor and peculiarity. There are really weird creatures to meet, or funny easter eggs for real life or other literature, for instance.

However, there is a main plotline to the game that is quite serious, even if a lot of the jokes and oddities might throw you off track. Many people might start off like I did, thinking that the game would just be a silly adventure into weirdness.

And while the game indeed keeps its quirkiness throughout the entirety of its time, the dialogue with characters and the storyline of the Fortunate Isles shows a real conflict over life and happiness. The Sea Will Claim Everything is filled with real life issues over government, news/word-of-mouth, work/employment, wealth, murder, philosophical beliefs, identity, and more.

You may continue to encounter bizarre scenes that make you look at the game as if it is crazy, but if you also focus on many serious encounters in the game, you will realize that there is something quite direct and real about the fantasy world you are visiting.

The Sea Will Claim Everything grew more interesting as I played it, though I will say that I did not read every single word or humorous scene that I encountered. I heavily focused on the plotline and more serious scenes, though I enjoyed many of the silly easter eggs along the way. The game's description on the Steam page notes "Walls of text" and it is very true. If you actually look at every single item description and read every single conversation word-for-word, your play time could be 3 times as much as mine, probably.

As mentioned earlier, the game's art style is mostly 2D without animation, with the exception of a few areas or specific scenes in the game. The art style still stands out as very nice, showing that a lot of work was put into it. There is an extremely large amount of areas to navigate in the game, and none of the exploration or backtracking ever felt boring to me. Part of that is owed to the game's ability to fast travel, and also the fact that  navigating between different areas is almost instantaneous.

Many of the places you explore also have their own distinct music, which further stands out as very interesting. I was taken aback at the number of songs in the game and the fact that many, many of them have a lot of quality work.

The Sea Will Claim Everything turned out to be an adventure that I unexpectedly loved. Quite a unique experience.

33655284.review:
When I first saw this on Greenlight, I thought it was some low-quality point and click that somehow got lost among the pile of uninspired platformers and boring first-person horror games. How wrong I was. 

This game has amazing worldbuilding. Despite its somewhat basic graphics, every scene has a lot of interactible elements, most of them rewarding you with strange creatures and items descriptions, puns, or twisted references to real-world things. There are sentient flowers and mushrooms (beware of the communist varieties), weird food and potions, technological plants (the game's UI is apparently made from them, and clicking its various doodads, that might look like they're just for show at first, will actually activate silly effects), and many more. The book titles in particular are great, whether they're referencing classics, fantasy and sci-fi, political and economical essays, videogames (particularly Morrowind, if you've ever played it you probably remember its peculiar literature), made-up authors or Greek writers I've never heard of. There might be a bit too much pseudoscientific stuff ("Revolving Protonic Chrono-Accumulator") and fantasy name salad ("King Xekmurg from Alkhirg") for my taste, but it's only a minor complaint. It all amounts to some kind of Frankensteinian setting, made of parts that should not work together but actually do. If you've read Harry Potter and wondered how Rowling managed to create an interesting setting while at first it seems she just threw every fantasy cliché ever into a soup, you'll get a similar feeling here.

The scenario is mostly used as a way to discover the world, although it's easy to spot it also delivers a social and political message (read: a left-winged political message, so you might not agree with it if you're leaning towards conservatism), since there are obvious nods to the Greek crisis and the Arab Spring. Despite the characters being mostly quest-givers and quest-receivers, they all have their little stories to tell, their own views on the world, and I ended up deeply caring for them (but it's easy to get hold of my emotions when you put cats and lizards everywhere).

Gameplay-wise it's a typical adventure game, click on things, get items, talk to characters, move the story forward. The few puzzles in there aren't particularly complex, or illogical (thankfully), and there's a quest log to keep track of what you need to do. It still has a few surprises in store, like the alchemy system.

While at first glance the graphics may look like they were drawn by a five-years-old, they're actually pretty competent in their use of coloring and shading. They give the game a peculiar atmosphere, somewhere between an illustrated book for children and an old PnP RPG manual from the 80s. 

There are other games in the same setting available from [url=http://landsofdream.net/games/]the authors' website[/url]. I haven't played them yet, so I can't say if they're as good as this one, but I'll mention their existence anyway.

+ Excellent worldbuilding
+ Likeable characters
+ Great writing
+ Quirky UI and alchemy mechanic
+ Many hidden things to find

- Political message might rub you the wrong way

9/10 It presents itself not as a videogame, but as a portal to another world. It may very well be.

32294160.review:
If you want to be a pedant (and I love nothing more than pedantry), you can boil almost any PC game down to clicking. Point-and-click adventures, obviously, but also puzzlers, simulators, and even FPSes if you go by the classic line about sniping being a point-and-click adventure where the only puzzle is Use Gun On Head. I bring this up because of all the clicking to be had in the gaming world, The Sea Will Claim Everything might be the most fun I've ever had clicking on things. Not because it's particularly pretty or complex clicking, but because what you get for it is so delightfully rewarding.

TSWCE is posed not as a game, but as a portal into the fanciful Lands of Dream. A fellow by the name of The Mysterious-Druid has grown this techno-organic interface for you so that you can help him solve a few pressing problems in his picturesque realm, namely the foreclosure of his equally techno-organic home, the disappearance of his girlfriend, and the political unrest threatening the Fortunate Isles. Luckily for you this portal functions much like a point-and-click adventure, with static scenes to click around, key phrases to initiate dialog with, items to find, combine, and use, and some other less-useful but plenty interesting features.

It's a cheeky premise for a game but you can't really appreciate how well it works until you get to that first scene and start clicking things. It's not a particularly strange scene, just a druid in a cave with a bunch of books and boxes and computery-things. But every single thing you click has a different, quirky description. And I mean EVERYTHING, every single book, every single mushroom, every single button, and every single bit of decor has something to say about its philosophy or political alignment or life goal or something equally irreverant. Scenes in this game brim with secrets where the reward is a clever line that's more than likely going to make you chuckle.

The Room and its sequel have long been my high-water mark for enjoyment just from clicking things, with every single switch and key and object having Blizzard-levels of tactile quality to clicking them. But TSWCE is an entirely new paradigm of clicking enjoyment, where every scene is full of things you just can't wait to click on because you'll be instantly regaled with loads of charm. That's really the key to making a great adventure game, giving players a world that is irresistible to explore, and while others have achieved that through graphics or story, this title does it through masterful writing.

That's not to say the story isn't a draw here, of course. The creativity and attention to detail that starts you off with a dimensional window in a techno-organic habitat extends fully to the rest of the game. The Fortunate Isles lie in the Lands of Dream, where goat people and elves and talking skulls and philosopher trees live and work side by side. Every one of them is a grounded, realistic character for what they are, fascinating to converse with without ever wearing out their welcomes. As your quest to aid The Mysterious-Druid unfolds you'll find a thread of plot that strongly echoes the hardships of our very real world, held aloft by subversions of myth, challengers of intellect, and some of the best writing to be found in gaming.

It took me a bit to warm up to the pace and style of this one, but rarely have I been so well-rewarded for sticking it out. Every element of the game is woven together with masterful artistry, from the detailed window that itself is used in puzzles to the random crafting experimentation that rewards you with more charming writing and secrets. You will never run out of discussions and descriptions to revel in, full of clever puns, thoughtful symbolism, and heartwarming plot. The Sea Will Claim Everything is a true treasure, a game of magnificent prose presented as rewards for exploring a rich and colorful world.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

A chameleon mushroom cleverly disguised as a short review.

The Sea Will Claim Everything will take you on a transplanar journey to the Lands of the Dream. 
And the writing will immediately be silly. And also intelligent. And sad. But oh so very silly! 
And it will soon evoke the feeling of calmness in you. Or it won't, and you will leave and play something else. But hopefully it will.

31871381.review:
A whimsical point and click adventure game with a narrative based around humanity and politics.

The point and click aspect of this game is almost all clicking on objects to read descriptions that are typically humorous. Occasionally you will need to find things in the environment and pick them up by clicking them individually. It's not common, and they're usually in your face. The rest of the game is really done through talking to characters and helping them so they can help you. Early on, I felt sort of pressured to click everything so I wouldn't miss anything important or funny.. there were tons of things to interact with. Eventually, after the first area, it's not so bad. There's also a ton of character that you may meet all at once, but the world layout makes it easy to run around quickly.

I really enjoyed the art style; it's cartoony, whimsical and colorful. I thought the music was superb as well, fitting the themes of the areas. The overall feel of the game is extremely calming, but it can feel kind of slow at times.

The game is best played alone with no distractions, as you do have to keep track of things you need to do. I would generally explore all the new areas before going back and completing the "quests", and a couple of times I found myself with too much to remember. There is a quest scroll you can look at that sums up what you have to do, but sometimes it's not descriptive enough... if you forget who you need to talk to, or where they are, you can spend a lot of time "lost." I got pretty far in the game before getting stuck... characters kept talking about a certain person that I was positive I never actually discovered in the world. I only ended up running into them by misclicking the navigation arrows. A couple of other quests seemed vague but didn't stop me up as much.

My biggest complaint is having to click the navigation arrows to move around. I wish I could use the arrow keys for this, so I wouldn't have to move my mouse around as much. Otherwise, the UI is quirky, but I feel like it added to the feel of the game.

I ended up enjoying the game more as it went on, and I really appreciated the small little details here and there. I don't think this game is for everybody, as there isn't a "twist" or anything crazy that happens like most games. It's simply an interactive story most of all, and a social commentary of the world secondly. There's a lot to like here, but it is a slow experience and not something you should rush through.

31265475.review:
I will begin with the easy part: I enjoyed The Sea Will Claim Everything very much. I have been a long-time player of adventure games, games with lots of text, interactive fiction, and as such felt very at home inside the "window" of the interface. It is possible that not everyone will share this level of comfort, but I'd encourage even such skeptics to consider trying it, or at least trying one of the free Lands of Dream titles. I really do think there is a place in everyone's life for games like this: something slow and thoughtful to savor and ponder.

There are a lot of reasons why I liked this game, and the other reviews on this page do a good job of explaining them, but I will reiterate for emphasis. The music in this game is wonderful and really, really adds a lot to the experience. The tone of the writing ranges from extremely silly to extremely poignant and somehow still feels like a unified whole. The characters you encounter are twenty different varieties of delightful, and I found myself caring about their stories much more than I expected. There's a point near the beginning of the game where (if I recall correctly) you are reading someone's journal to discover a crucial yet mundane piece of information to solve a puzzle. The entries continued on beyond the point when I learned what I needed to, and by the end I was overwhelmed and misty-eyed over this person's story--and they don't even appear anywhere else in the game. That's when I knew I was playing something really special.

So, I'd say the thing I liked most about this game was the characters. Actually, as I played through the game I started to realize that essentially everything in the game's world is a character. Every rock, every flower, every box, every mushroom. Some of the beings you encounter just talk to you more than others. And this struck me as a very lovely idea: that life is a kind of fractal, that everything has its own story and experiences, that some kind of universality connects even things that seem utterly disconnected. And the game has a great many more ideas.

I am not sure I have anything particularly negative to say about my time playing. There were two places I got stuck: once because I hadn't searched an area exhaustively enough, and once because I forgot about certain capabilities I possessed. But overall the level of frustration was low. 

In summary, I think people who know they like this kind of game will really like it. And I want to re-emphasize for everyone else who is not sure: try it and I think you will be pleasantly delighted.

This game is so excellent. It's hard to concisely describe why, but I want to sum it up as a sense of place and being. This game has such a strong sense of being a real (albeit fantastical) place that you're visiting with environments and characters so filled with life and nuance. There's a strong characteristic of whimsy sprinkled throughout the scenes, which is something that few games have. Most of all, I like visiting a place with such varied, complex characters with thoughts and feelings that go far far beyond typical game tropes and archetypes. It makes me want to discover more and more about every location and every single person. So much POV about politics, science, society and things that are so trivial when we think about it. This game made me think about so much things. The philosophy in this game is brilliant. Absolutely brilliant. The puzzles are also very good and it advances in a very good flow (unfortunately, I couldn't find out how to make a cookie for that cute lizard). And of course, the comedy. I laughed a lot during some dialogues. 
Hands down to Verena as well. Such amazing art that is so simple but so full of soul. I really liked all the details, from the tiny mushrooms to the amazing landscapes. And the music is warm, homely and it makes me wanna live in some islands at Lands of Dream.

But I gotta agree with one of the reviews here that says Jonas shouldn't have focused on one side of real-life politics when making some jokes. It could have been neutral or maybe show more of the other one. But this is just a very tiny detail.

Well, I wish I could see Oneiropolis one day. I also wonder when Lord Urizen will show up...

Nonetheless, 10/10 to TSWCE. I already was a fan before playing this game, but now... I'm #1 fan =D

29771272.review:
If you had to pick a genre, then the above would qualify as an adventure game. You find items with which you complete puzzles, and the puzzles are more whimsical and fun than annoyingly abstract or frustratingly stupid. You explore a fantastical world, and are set to help a druid repair his home which is partly alive and partly mechanical -- built out of "druidic technomagic". A story emerges out of this exploration.

It really captures a dreamworld very well, being both serious and silly, magical and concrete. I think the above is particularly interesting as a game because I think it would appeal to people who are not normally "gamer" people -- the real attraction is the story and setting and art more than the adventure game aspects. Not that gamers wouldn't enjoy the game if they happen to like adventure games in the first place, but I would recommend it to anyone who just likes a good story.

Especially great for your socialist kiddos and families. :D

29650843.review:

29292791.review:
Dalla fervida mente di Jonas Kyratzes, uno degli autori di Talos Principle (questo però l'ha fatto prima), TSWCE è una classica avventura grafica a schermate fisse, ma con un sacco di elementi testuali, surreali, metagame e genialità assortite. 

Ambientato in un mondo fantastico popolato da animali antropomorfi, umani normali e tutto quello che vi sta nel mezzo, noi siamo chiamati a evitare che Underhome, la strana dimora biotecnologica nella quale veniamo evocati, venga sottoposta al pignoramento illegittimo da parte delle banche. Nel farlo, ci avventureremo anche all'esterno, nelle tre isole di cui è composto il mondo di gioco, incontrando personaggi bizzarri, risolvendo i loro problemi e scontrandoci nel mentre con i poteri forti che governano da quelle parti.

Nonostante l'apparenza soft e fantasy, TSWCE è in realtà un gioco fortemente caratterizzato da una critica sociale al capitalismo, ai soprusi esercitati da amministrazioni locali corrotte, alla politica ottusa e cieca ai problemi della gente, insomma, avete capito. Ci sono temi molto impegnati, evidentemente molto cari all'autore e ben evidenti nel sottotesto del gioco, ma intelligentemente mascherati dietro una storia tutto sommato semplice e fiabesca. 

La colonna sonora si compone di una manciata di brani orecchiabili che caratterizzano alla perfezione ogni isola, mentre ogni schermata è splendidamente disegnata a mano. Una delle trovate migliori del gioco (e quello che gli avrà preso più tempo), però, sono le descrizioni, di tutto. Seriamente, se in una schermata ci sono 100 scatole disegnate, si può cliccare letteralmente su ognuna di esse, e leggere cosa contiene. Le descrizioni spaziano da quelle più seriose al nonsense al "sarà una citazione ma non l'ho capita", ma è una cosa che ti invoglia a cliccare su tutto per vedere cosa si è inventato. Idem per l'enorme mole di libri, di funghi ("Questo fungo è molto arrogante") o per quasi qualsiasi cosa sia su schermo.  

Questo mi sembra il momento giusto per precisare anche che tutto il gioco è solo in inglese, non troppo difficile, ma c'è davvero tanto, tanto testo riguardante anche argomenti più seri come filosofia e politica, perciò tenetelo a mente.  
Non dura moltissimo, sulle 5-6 ore, e gli enigmi e le quest sono abbastanza semplici da risolvere (a parte un paio di casi più… creativi), ma nonostante le tematiche che spesso mette in campo riesce a mantenere alta l'attenzione fino alla fine e a strappare più di una risata con le sue trovate assurde e geniali.

29084527.review:
Are you part of The Sea Will Claim Everything's impossibly small ideal audience? Left-wing fans of point-and-click adventures, willing to read walls of text and forgive cludgy interface to experience a labor of love? If you're even just most of that, TSWCE is worth a shot.  The game is *insanely not for everyone* but those who like it will find a lot to love.

The hand-drawn interface is primitive, but the music and writing have more than enough maturity to make up for it. Its sense of humor tends toward the "quirky" side but it usually stays clear enough of forced "randomness" to stay endearing. There are some light puzzles but most of the content is experienced by talking with the inhabitants of the Fortunate Isles and carrying about ideas and conversation topics from place to place. Two puzzles that have to be brute-forced telegraph this in advance. Overall, puzzles are fair. 

But it's the story that makes TSWCE worth your stay. As a trans-planar visitor to the Land of Dreams, you find the Fortunate Isles in disarray, shaken by economic turmoil and a rightward-creeping kleptocracy. If you know what that means, you're in the right place. If you don't, TSWCE is loaded with sympathetic characters who make the politics of the Fortunate Isles concrete and real. You'll get more out of it if you know the basic contours of the Greek Debt Crisis, but even if you don't, you'll easily figure out who's on the side of common people and who's lining their pockets off the misery of others. You'll use wild biotechnology and come face to face with creatures of myth and legend as you learn about what can be done to save the Fortunate Isles.

It's a short game but an absolutely one-of-a-kind experience and if you take your time to read and enjoy this dense heap of words, it will return so much of the love that was clearly put into it.

29046241.review: Невероятная история, чем-то напоминающая companion of xanth, и разные другие олдскульные игоры. Очень стильная, с прекрасной музыкой. Абсолютно логичная, нет никаких затупов, не надо в интернетах искать решения загадок, всё есть. Каждый предмет обладает смешным описанием. Также очень рекомендую почитать pdf в каталоге игры. :)

29023312.review:
Un juego que más bien se trata de una novela interactiva, con unos pocos puzzles que requieren cierta interacción. Está magníficamente escrito y abunda en detalles y referencias, el autor es el guionista de The Talos Principle, un juego que se ha ganado una buena reputación en un mercado más amplio que el público al que puede llegar The Sea Will Claim Everything.

El juego está ambientado en la Tierra de los Sueños, una ambientación donde el autor ha dado rienda suelta s sus obsesiones, sus pensamientos, sus ideas y todo tipo de influencias de su vida. Desde los libros que más le han interesado a su ideología política. Y esto queda muy claro tras jugar a TSWCE, ya que todo el juego es una enorme parábola sobre Grecia, la crisis, Europa, los mercados, la Primavera Árabe y otros conflictos recientes en Oriente Medio; así como un manual revolucionario que incita a pensar por sí mismo, a perseguir cambiar el mundo a mejor, a no cerrar los ojos ante las injusticias y a enfocar de una forma madura que las acciones tienen consecuencias y no debemos temer pasar a la acción en lugar de lamentarnos constantemente.
 Este juego es uno de esos pocos que dejan un buen sabor de poca al terminarlo, un sabor duradero y emocionante, con un final que se extiende durante una larga media hora, opcional, en la que puedes ir despidiéndote de todos los personajes que pueblan las Islas Afortunadas. Algo que se echa mucho en falta en una enorme cantidad de títulos.

 El apartado gráfico, si bien tosco, tiene cierto encanto. Ilustraciones hechas a mano por la misma autora, entre lo naif de un cuento infantil y el horrore vacui de las obras más barrocas que se pueden imaginar. Pese a no ser unas buenas ilustraciones, en mi opinión, uno no tarda en cogerles el gusto y en verlas de un modo algo adecuado al tono del juego.
 La música es magnífica y es uno de esos juegos que no he querido cerrar a veces por dejarlo sonar de fondo. Un sobresaliente en este apartado.
 
 Finalmente, sobre el modo de juego en sí: no conviene coger este juego como un juego tradicional. Se trata de una interfaz tosca donde ir curioseando en los elementos, leyendo una gran cantidad de texto y adentrándose con cierta ayuda de la historia y el tono de las ilustraciones y la música en un mundo de fantasía donde por una parte se ven ecos de nuestro mundo de una forma muy clara y por otra  sirve como cápsula de escpae donde evadirse y leer tranquilamente. Si vas a jugar a este juego, hazlo como si leyeses un libro.

 Como nota aparte, el autor tiene un blog temático sobre la Tierra de los Sueños, http://landsofdream.net/ que recomiendo visitar si te gusta el juego. Una gran cantidad de historias brillantes, entradas desternillantes y todo tipo de reflexiones en las que anima al lector a ignorar a los padres que se opongan a que sus hijos jueguen a sus juegos, ya que el aspecto puede ser infantil, peor en última instancia, el contenido no lo es.
 En esta web se pueden encontrar los demás juegos que ha hecho temáticos sobre este mundo (The Sea Will Claim Everything sería en orden el último hasta la fecha, aunque el orden se sitúa de un modo que.. es mejor verlo en la web), muchos de ellos gratuitos.

 Finalmente: el juego está totalmente en inglés y no tiene pinta de que vaya a estar disponible nunca en castellano, avisado queda quien esté interesado en el tema del idioma.

 Pese a lo cutre que pueda parecer, The Sea Will Claim Everything es uno de los juegos más intensos y hermosos a los que he jugado nunca, y cuyo siguiente juego (The Council of Crows, en desarrollo a día de hoy) compraré según salga.

29010091.review:
[h1][b]Champiñones comunistas, camaleones disfrazados de camaleón y deuda sudeuropea[/b][/h1]

Hay veces que hacen falta muy pocos recursos para llegar a la parte más profunda de nuestro interior. Ese pequeño resorte que todos guardamos y que, como por arte de magia, abre una puerta que deja fluir el yo más privado. Un yo que conecta con todo aquello que nos rodea, que es capaz de observar el mundo de manera más clara, que es hipersensible con la materia. Un yo más puro, capaz de conectar con la humanidad. Se dice que todos somos como pequeñas islas y que, a través del mar, estamos conectados unos entre otros...

Llegué a Jonas Kyratzes a través del maravilloso [i]The Talos Principle[/i]. Un juego con unos puzzles muy interesantes pero sobre todo con una narrativa escandalosa, algo muy por encima de lo habitual en el mundo de los videojuegos. Busqué quién había escrito esa barbaridad y apunté el nombre mentalmente. Se me olvidó al tiempo, por supuesto. Hasta que no sé muy bien cómo llegué a [i]The Sea Will Claim Everything[/i], y ahí estaba su nombre de nuevo.

Pero no se parecía en nada a lo que había visto antes en él. No, en serio. Esto aparentaba un cuento infantil con una interfaz arcaica y propia de principios de los 90 más que algo rompedor y por encima de lo habitual en el mundo de los videojuegos. Aún así, pues bueno, esperé la ocasión en que me sobraran unos cuantos euros para hacerme con él. Todo para descubrir que estaba en lo cierto: que es un cuento infantil con una interfaz arcaica y propia de principios de los 90. Y, ¿sabes qué? Que es maravilloso.

[i]"Sometimes I wonder whether we haven’t accepted too many injustices simply because the sunshine makes us feel good despite our poverty."[/i]

Es maravilloso encontrarse con una pieza tan surrealista, pletórica de humor y vastísima en tantos detalles. Busca una ilustración. Míralo todo bien. Hay muchos libros, como 100 al menos. Pulsa en cada uno de ellos y descubre que todos tienen su título propio, y es más, que todos ellos son tremendamente divertidos. Oh vaya, aquí hay muchos champiñones. Unos están formando una familia. Otros están leyendo el Ulises de Joyce, pero la versión leíble, no la otra. Otros están no, espera, estos son camaleones disfrazados de champiñones. Otros conspiran contra el gobierno.

Contra un gobierno, elegido por el propio pueblo, que ha creado una deuda ilegítima y que en pos del progreso ahora ahoga al mismo pueblo que lo ha elegido. Así, sin darte cuenta. De repente, una historia de lo más surrealista va cambiando, como el agua de los ríos, hasta convertirse en algo más, en una imagen real del sur de Europa. Y ese gato que vende pescado en el mercado, ese pequeño ratón que tiene una pequeña taberna para ratones a las puertas de la taberna para humanos, ese pulpo que da el acceso al faro de la isla desde la que se divisan las costas, así de repente, todos ellos cobran una humanidad tan grande que es dolorosa.

[i]"I’ve been told that I need to change to being a man, because that would be preferable in a guard. I thought the revolution was all about getting rid of that sort of thing."[/i]

Es un mecanismo extraño, ¿sabes? Ese que hace que conectes con tu parte más infantil, esa que tienes cerrada bajo llave no sabes muy bien por qué, quizás porque alguien dijo que no está bien para un adulto ser un niño. Y que, desde esa sensación a infancia, realices un pequeño viaje astral al mundo de los adultos. Sin perder tu conciencia actual de mayor, pero desde tus ojos de niño. La vida cobra terribles significados, y esas cosas que te parecían muy alegres ya no te lo parecen tanto. Y no entiendes muy bien qué ha pasado para que los mayores hayamos tomado esas decisiones tan malas. Y haciendo eso, [i]The Sea Will Claim Everything[/i] juega con maestría soberbia. En disociar cuerpo y mente, a través de ilustraciones infantiles y diálogos hilarantes, en conversaciones sin sentido alguno para que sin esperarlo recibas un duro golpe de realidad y te preguntes, ¿cómo hemos llegado aquí? ¿Por qué hemos permitido esto?

La verdad, no sé muy bien qué decirte. Cómo convencer a alguien de que esas ilustraciones tan toscas que ves ahí arriba son mucho más. Que este juego es mucho más que un juego. Que es un pequeño libro rebosante de alegría, tragedia y humanidad. Que quizás, si eres paciente y por un momento puedes ver un poco más allá, puedas entender este maravilloso regalo que Jonas Kyratzes ha hecho al mundo gamer. Se dice que todos somos como pequeñas islas...

[i]"...And so the sea claimed Moira and Robert, as they say it will claim everything in the end".[/i]

28508263.review:
It's... interesting.  I can't really fault this game for being what it is.  But what it is maybe just isn't for me, and that's because I'm me.

[h1]-Story-[/h1]
The story of this game is that you-the-player are a guest in the Land of Dreams.  You run around various isles helping the whimsical pseudo-philosophical people with their troubles and trade items around to solve some puzzles.  A lot of people are oppressed by their more serious skeleton governors and an evil skeleton general, and you help them make the bad guys go away.  Its not presented in a childish manner as my description might seem (and by childish I mean overly sanitized), and there's some deep language / concepts being presented... but I think really the problem is that I've grown up.  Its a bit [b]too[/b] abstract and whimsical for me.  I am someone who is very open and self-analytical about his thoughts and feelings, so what's presented in the game feels like an invitation to something I have explored quite well already.  Abstractions about change and the future and identity and hard times and all, I see it and nod my head not in dismissal but in recognition.  Its also the way it goes about it, as I just dont find that insightful figures of speech and deep metaphorical quandaries as useful as directly thinking about the topic in question.  So this might be a very good game for someone who hasn't so thoroughly explored themselves, but not for me.  "You can always explore yourself more!" you might say.  And that's probably true for adults who haven't got a good grasp of themselves and their own beliefs (and boy are there a lot of these).  Maybe it sounds arrogant but believe me, I know myself.  I've done that.  So the game just doesn't have that much for me.  All that being said the game wasn't a complete bore or anything as I might seem to be implying.  Some characters had some dialogue that I nodded my head in recognition of and in general I agreed with the tone of the story.

The other problem is that the game carries the kind of humorous tone that I have never liked.  I don't have a great word for it, but I always call it the 'Hitchhiker's Guide humor.'  Basically, random nonsense descriptions or dialogue added just to be random because nonsense is humorous.  Its not for me.  Saying that an eyeball plant loves to play Borderlands with a character first name 'The' last name 'Mysterious-Druid', or that a drawer is full of water with a family of sardines inside, or a dog that talks like can haz cheezburg, or random dialogue about plants chatting happily or conspiring about something mysterious whatever isn't funny to me.  It never has been, and never will be.

[h1]-Gameplay-[/h1]
There's not a whole lot to get in depth with about gameplay.  You talk to NPCs, follow what they ask you about and generally fulfill their requests without much puzzling about.  If there's any gripe its in a few nitpicks of game design for the benefit of the player.  

One is if you walked away from the game and came back you might end up horribly lost as some NPCs don't repeat dialogue that gives hints and you need a collection of items from them to complete the game.  These are lumped in under one objective (collecting tokens) without more information so the details will be lost on you if you dont keep the game fresh in your mind.  You'd have to talk to a lot of NPCs again to figure out what you were looking for.

Another is that its possible to miss a few items and not know where to find them.  For example, 'Tremendous toadstool' is one such item.  There's a lot of mushrooms in this game.  Eventually I just stopped clicking on them because they only gave Hitchhiker Humor quotes for doing so, and thus I ended up passing by this item and having to resort to a guide because it didn't ever occur to me that this one which doesn't appear to be exceptional in any way might be an item I needed.  I could see this occurring for someone with other items too, or not thinking to revisit one or another NPC and getting a bit lost, or forgetting how to turn off the screen for the Unspeakable Cave.  Going back to The Mysterious-Druid for a clue might have been useful for the mushroom, I'm not sure if other NPCs give hints for the cave and so on.  I also had to use the guide to find the fireproof gloves as I had somehow missed the safe key needed to acquire them, thinking I had explored the Underhome completely.  Hunting every room all over again would have been a small chore.  Once again, asking The MD would have been helpful here as they would likely know where the key to the safe was.

[h1]-Performance-[/h1]
Suffice it to say this game will not tax your computer in much any way that I can imagine.  No bugs that I could detect and the game never crashed.  Music was blaringly loud even when set to lowest in game and 1/100 on my headset.  I had to resort to speakers instead.  Playtime is about 2.5 hours, but I got this in a bundle somewhere over a year ago probably for around the price of almost nothing.  I think the length is fair for the game, you could definitely take the game a bit slower.

The aesthetic of the game is kind of passable, its not meant to impress as much be a visual cue, which is fine.  I've played other games like that which I thoroughly enjoyed, although this game did not greatly grow on me.  The music is okay, not unpleasant to listen to so that's good.

[h1]-Summary-[/h1]
This again where I wish I could give more of a neutral recommendation.  I really just don't know what to think of the game.    I would probably say that its okay for others to play it for an introspective angle, but I'm sure a lot of people would be turned off by the graphics and not let themselves get much into the game and the genre (hidden object/p&c) isn't a popular one these days either.  [b]Ultimately, I dont recommend the game even if I don't have a good reason to recommend against it.[/b]  It just wasn't a game for me.

EDIT: Reading the PDF that comes with the game gives some more insight into the thought that went into making the game.  The story being an expression of the personal plights of the developer does make sense.  Those plights arent trivial, and that insight does improve my feelings on the game somewhat, but making a game about a personal story isn't by itself enough.  The game has to stand on its own too, so my rating will remain the same.

28192613.review:
This a very strange and charming per-screen-based first person view point and click adventure game that has surprisingly good writing, strange quirky humour and interesting life and philosophy musings. This is also the first commercial game from the same writer that brought you the story of The Talos Principle, which is probably a selling point of it's own.

This game... well, this portal to a different world is quite peculiar. It's full of buttons and switches, some of which are helpful and some of which make funny noises. And that different world is both surprisingly charming and funny and quite painfully real. Full of quite unexpectidly well put pop culture references (so many games fail at maintaining their own feel while doing this, after all), weird creatures and unpleasant bureaucracy.

There are moments of "okay now what", and it does want you to calm down and pay attention to everything and not click through text, so it requires a specific mood and mindset to be enjoyable properly. But when you're ready for it (or, more like - you THINK you're ready for it), The Sea Will Claim Everything is a joy. Mouse thinks it's a bit overrated, though.

28146030.review:
SPOILERS AHEAD, BUT NOT FOR IMPORTANT PLOT DETAILS.

A quick clarification: I do, technically, spoil the last sequence of the game's ending. But the main part of the game is not the ending, so it shouldn't spoil actual enjoyment of the game.

I'm torn regarding this game. Firstly, it took me about four hours to complete, more or less doing everything possible, and since it's more of an interactive novel than a game, I doubt you can get much more out of it.

I enjoyed the game, but there is a caveat and that's the completely unsubtle political overtones to the game. The designers of the game are Greek, and have taken the country's current financial troubles and made a game about it, set in a fantasy land where all the good guys have Greek names and all the bad guys have German names. One is called Angela Merkel, or close to it, and there's even a Hitler reference in the game. It ends with the Germans about to declare war on the Greeks because they had the temerity to stand up to German bankers.

If you think all this sounds fabulous then go right ahead, but if you aren't Greek, or have a more nuanced view of how macroeconomics works, you might think that the authors are maybe being a little bit racist-y.

28123404.review:
Parler de ce jeux n'est pour moi pas évident puisqu'il est clairement tres engagé politiquement et je ne me sens pas vraiment a l'aise pour analyser cette facette du jeu, mais je peux parler du reste de ce que j'ai tant aimé dans cette petite pépite alors essayons :

Pour 10€, on se retrouve face a un curieux objet videoludique, un Point&Clic entièrement en anglais  demandant un bon niveau puisqu'il faudra lire (beaucoup), des graphismes fait mains peu attrayants au départ mais qui ont leur charme une fois acceptés et une durée d'approximativement 5h/6h

Pour rentrer plus en détail on peut parler de son interface plutot originale, lancer le jeu correspond a lancer un fenetre vers un autre monde, celui des "Fortunate Isles", un monde exotique, plutot satirique et pourtant familier dans ses références et ses enjeux que je vous laisse le plaisir de découvrir. 
Cette interface/fenetre permet de communiquer et d'interargir avec les différents habitants qui sont "conscients" que vous n'etes pas de leur monde et qui ont grand besoin d'aide.

Si "The sea will claim everithing" suit les codes basiques du point&clic dans son histoire et son gameplay, l'écriture et les descriptions de ce monde m'ont enchanté a chaques instant, on se retrouve a cliquer un peu partout dans le décors pour en découvrir un peu plus sur cet univers.

On y trouve des champignons (beaucoup) et d'autres curiosités telles que un techno-druide passionné de biologie, un homme arbre philosophe et de nombreuses références culturelles geek et communistes.


Pour finir en attendant la prchaine aventure, quelques mot-clef que ce jeu m'inspire :

Champignons, Science, Bienveillance, Partage, Refus, Alchimie, Mélancolique, Libertaire

27920448.review:
I love this game.  I *LOVE* this game.  It always sounded interesting and quirky, and I never had a clear idea of what it was about; recently I decided to fire it up and take a look.  And I *love* this GAME.  

Right off the bat, I have to say: it's not going to be for everyone.  It's gentle and thoughtful, and there's a lot of reading.  It's a game that wants patience, and we won't need our guns and shields here.  The story is dense and rich and peopled by curious daffy folk: ancient trees, talking animals, dwarves and elves and leprechauns and Greek mythological beings.  They're not drawn from a single universe, they're drawn from many, so our elf in the market greets us "Mae gevonnen," and our Mysterious Druid, from the long-lined Mysterious-Druid family, is more a hippie organic Let-It-Be sort of fellow.  His partner does science experiments with her Quadricorder.   

We start in the Underhome, five floors and a cellar of tree-like habitat.  We have no idea what's going on, and The Mysterious-Druid isn't much help.  A little, but not much.  Thugs from the Mayor have been over, threatening foreclosure, and they broke some stuff and upset the tree - they even ripped up the rug, which I gather really held the room together.  We'll need to get to the bottom of things, but first we'll need to calm and repair the Underhome enough that it will open the door and let us out into the world. 

There are mushrooms and books and organic machines all over the place - and every mushroom, every book, and every flower in the game has individual text when we click on them.  Every one is a hoot.  The book titles range from real to hilarious to fanciful, with references scattered through fandoms of every sort.  The mushrooms and flowers aspire to this and that, and some are communist.  There are several islands, which we can't visit until we find a compass and a sextant.  The sextant is hard.  We need to break into a tomb, and find the roots of the corruption, and of course tend to the Underhome and its garrulous, helpless residents. 

There's a political message about brutalism and corruption stealing heart and life from the good and various citizens running strong through the game; I gather it specifically alludes to the collapse of the Greek economy within the EU, but these days many of us will find that the details may have changed, but the overall picture has not.  The message, ultimately, is one of wise and weary faith in the decency of time and the resilience of people.  I found it ultimately really beautiful, and this game is my nominee for the "I'm Not Crying" category in the new Steam awards.  

So I'll call it "quirky," but it's so much more than that.  Better to say that it's bursting with personality, that creativity is leaking out at the edges.  It's booky, geeky, lovingly wise creativity, spread though the wild and static characters who live on these islands.  Frankly, I couldn't ever quite put my finger on it, and I was always eager to see what leap of fancy would come next.

First run took me about 8.5 hours; I had to go back to catch up on a missing achievement, thus my longer total time spent.

23858981.review:
It's hard to write a review about a game that's so beautifully crafted but with whose central conceits you take so much issue.

The lands of Dream, within which the game is set, is more whimsical than really vividly imagined. There isn't really a clear set of rules that comes through; instead it's a flight of whimsy whose philosophizing is so ever-present that the game fails to hide its true purpose as a delivery system for these ideas.

I really find it a shame that such a gifted writer is so solidly steeped in one philosophy in particular, making references again and again to every communist thinker and writer from the likes of Marx all the way down to China Mieville. It's so much more interesting if the writer isn't so eager to reach his conclusion, instead presenting problems with multiple possible answers and allowing his audience to salt to taste.

But make no mistake -- this is a message game, and so I must address the message.

Kyratzes waxes poetic on the unnaturally destructive nature of debt, on capitalism as destructive force, etc. But the problem is that communists -- including Kyratzes -- again and again attack capitalism for the sins of corporatist mercantilism. Debt is destroying nations from Greece to the US because central banks fix interest rates so as to allow their governments to pay low interest on national debt. But this also drops the price of debt for everybody.

Meanwhile, oligarch kingpins -- the proverbial robber barons of old -- turn from very successful businessmen such as Jeff Bezos in to corrupt plutocrats like Rockefeller (or Jeffrey Immelt, frankly) by using their resources to corrupt the laws, writing new ones to destroy their competition through regulations that benefit them at the expense of other businesses.

This is not capitalism. This is corporatism and it's mercantilism.

Capitalism must have law as its foundation -- that is, the rules of the game must be the same for all players. This way creativity and innovation is rewarded. We can see this in the video gaming industry. Without publisher gatekeepers a more liquid market has emerged allowing guys like Kyratzes to compete with big developers on merit rather than market buying power.

Capitalism is necessarily tied to republics, because the nature of republics restricts the legal powers of the government, creating enough stability in the law for people to invest their money and start businesses. 

Our (the US) republic has been corrupted for many years, the law weakened and co-opted for oligarchs' benefit. This happened by replacing many foundational laws under the banner of direct democracy, or majority rule. The majority is bought with money via media, and the crumbling law allows mercantilist oligarchy to take its place. THIS is the devil that communists point to and eroneously call 'capitalism.'

Meanwhile, Kyratzes' Greece is experiencing the wrath of bond markets looking at a fiscally insolvent country that cannot bail itself out by printing money. Greece is experiencing the effects of european central control, not the effects of capitalism.

Communism is unworkable for two simple reasons:

Firstly, man is not omniscient. There is no possible way a committee of experts can accurately predict the actual number of boots demanded by a people. The only way this can actually be done is via the price system that market economies use. But a communist system hasn't any prices, and so planners must guess at this, thus creating regular and inefficient shortages and gluts.

Secondly, equal income for all actually means a vast underclass with an extremely small ruling class. This is necessary because somebody has to decide goods production levels for the society, and the man who does this holds absolute power over everything. How many boots should be manufactured? Of course, this man will need a number of political appointee experts to assist him. Thus an extremely small, fabulously wealthy ruling class that decides the fate of everybody else. No income gap is the same as a VAST income gap. And it follows that communism is necessarily ALWAYS tied to oligarchy, because somebody has to make the production decisions. The idea that economic systems and political systems are discreet and separate is plainly absurd. 

Communists like Kyratzes have a fantasy that personal freedom can exist arm in arm with communism, but this is an impossibility. Command and control economies require command and control governments to operate them. A republic under this system is a republic in name only. Representatives bow to the wishes of the heirarchical bureaucratic planners who bring the bill to the legislature, and the planners -- who control the fates of all and thus hold all the power -- ensure that the reps who are elected are those that play ball.

Further, the idea that personal and economic freedom are separate is again illusory. The freedom to make something and sell it is fundamental to the freedom to speak, to write, to live. The planners in a socialist system can simply remove the appointed job from any dissenters. And private profit -- an alternative way to make a living should one lose his job -- is illegal.

The simple fact remains that while governments never REALLY care about personal freedoms that don't threaten them -- like the freedom to dance, or the freedom to praise the government -- it is controversial speech and controversial action that must be protected.

Under a capitalist republic naive intellectuals like Kyratzes are free to promote their wrong-headed thinking, and disseminate their views unimpeded. But in a communist society ideas of liberty and markets see dissenters on the wrong end of a rope.

Kyratzes is clearly a brilliantly contemplative person, and I imagine he would present the counter argument as well should he have heard it. But contemporary intellectualism is often an echo chamber, and I doubt that Mr Kyratzes has read F.A. Hayek, or Mises, or Garet Garrett, or he might present both points of view and leave his readers to decide for themselves.

That said, Kyratzes' brilliant writing makes this game the most pleasant proselytism I can imagine. Yet that it is nevertheless.

23829054.review:
The Sea Will Claim Everything is a bare bones graphic adventure, with simple puzzles and an over-reliance on pixel hunting. You're presented with single-image nodes and interact with "hotspots" by clicking on them - save for a few exceptions, there are no inventory or verb puzzles; you automatically use the correct object (if you have it) when needed.
 But wait.
 It's also hyperliterate, full of offbeat humor and loveable characters. It's imaginative to a fault, gentle, and filled with warmth. The story and the writing are excellent. So is the music.
 I normally loathe pixel hunting in adventure games, but here it's turned into a strength - rooms often have dozens of objects to interact which, each one of their descriptions a joy to read.
 The simplistic puzzling would be a problem, except that here it fits the game's pacing to a tee. And it still feels satisfying, mostly because it still depends on exploring the environments thoroughly.

 Listen, this is one of the loveliest things I've played in a long time. If good, well-written stories interest you in any way, and you're not allergic to lo-fi graphic adventures, I recommend this game whole heartedly.

23795013.review:
I began playing this game on January 1st, 2015 (before it was on Steam), and finished it the next day. Prior to playing, I was a conservative kid raised to believe every word Glenn Beck said. Today, I am a communist. And it's ALL THIS GAME'S FAULT!

You see, I belong to a narrow generation of youth who grew up on Flash games. Even today, the only consoles in the house are a Wii and a DS Lite, each with just a handful of games. It started with regular visits to Club Penguin and Miniclip, then Nitrome, and, as my desire for innovation grew, Casual Gameplay @ JayisGames. I subscribed to JayisGames on Google Reader (RIP) and once every few weeks, I scrolled through and clicked on everything interesting. This is how I discovered the work of Jonas and Verena Kyratzes. (Aside: this is also how I discovered Ludum Dare, where I would soon enter my own rudimentary games.)

I fell headfirst into the dreamy wonder of The Infinite Ocean, the lost world of Alphaland, and of course, the sweet laughter behind The Book of Living Magic. If I had to pin down what attracted me to those games, I would say "emotional payoff" -- these games, unlike most others, gave me an indescribable feeling somehow related to beauty. This feeling would cause me to babble on to my best friend for days about the games, especially The Infinite Ocean, its ambiguous plot quite the exercise for my 13-year-old brain. These games gave me my earliest notion that videogames could be art.

Now, I knew that Jonas's games were in support of communism, and that communism was antithetical to everything I then believed, but that only made them more intriguing. Bored of Fox's strawmen, I began frequenting Jonas's blog, cultivating his strong challenges to my beliefs. I even wrote a story in the comments once to counter him, but I'm afraid to dig that up, haha.

The Sea Will Claim Everything was the Kyratzes' first paid game, and being that I was a Kid With No Money, it was a several years before I bought and played it. And, well...

Games are about overcoming challenges. Your standard videogame challenges you to kill things before things kill you. But other games present a more meaningful challenge. Undertale, for example, challenges us to empathize with those hostile towards us. The Sea Will Claim Everything challenges your view of society.

You can fall in love with the Fortunate Isles like your own home, because these are the characters' homes. You can grieve the pillaging of the Isles and give your best to help, only for Lord Urizen's men to take everything away. Through the Lands of Dream, you can feel for the plight of humanity in our waking world.

But what really turned me to communism were the mushrooms. They look so dashing in red.

22156844.review:
The Sea Will Claim Everything is one of those amazing niche games that you can't help but fall in love with. It has a similar style to classic graphical adventure games: travel around to various locations, click on hot spots to collect items, read description, or perform actions, and complete quest objectives.

What makes it stand out as such a special and exceptional game is the immense love that has gone into this hand-crafted world. The graphics are hand-drawn, and charmingly so. The story is well-written, with engaging characters and surprising depth. It's one of those games where you actually care about the people in it. Almost every tiny thing in the world can be clicked on to read a description, and everything is so wonderfully quirky, you actually want to click on every last thing and read the details. There are so many hidden surprises to be found, exploring the world is worth the price alone. (In fact, it's worth trying to click on everything in the game window, as there are several weird and unexpected results.)

Because everything in the world is detailed in such a wonderful way, it can be easy to overlook how well the simple gameplay suits the genre. In classic adventure games, there are often multiple modes for the mouse cursor, but TSWCE doesn't need a cursor that switches between a hand and an eye and so on -- if you can pick something up, you will. If there is an interaction to be had, it occurs. It allows you to focus on the immersion without worrying that you missed picking something up or turning something on.

Perhaps most importantly, the game treats you like a person. This may sound a weird thing, but it's a wonderfully weird game, and one that's worth playing after you've "beaten" it and solved the main plotline's problems.

It really is a special game and a special experience. Charming, engaging, curious, and wonderful. I can't recommend it enough.

22138527.review:
The Sea Will Claim Everything is a charming and unique point & click adventure game, with an engaging story that betrays its storybook visuals; it balances wry humour and silliness with a strong narrative exploring both political and philisophical themes, a hallmark of Jonas Kyratzes' writing. If you're familiar with his work on The Talos Principle, you should have a good idea of what to expect.

It will subvert your expectations of more traditional adventure games and draw you into the wonderfully bizarre world full of interesting and unique characters, all brought to life with lovingly hand-drawn art and fantastic soundtrack. It'd probably be easy to dismiss it as 'just an adventure game', merely describing the story or features wouldn't change your mind on that, but it's ultimately more than the sum of its parts and an experience that is both entertaining and thought provoking.

It's not entirely without flaws, but the faults I have with it are minor, pedantic at best, and don't detract from the overall quality in any significant way. My only real criticism would be that it's somewhat short, although not in a way that the story felt rushed or not long enough, moreso that I just didn't really want it to end.

While it may not appeal to everyone, The Sea Will Claim Everything is a game that deserves far more attention and one that more people should try. If you're still unsure, there is a demo available [url=http://landsofdream.net/games/the-sea-will-claim-everything/demo/]here[/url], where you can also play the other games in the Lands of Dream series for free (which you should).

22112023.review: This is, in a nutshell, the most interesting, well-written, and entertaining adventure game I've ever had the pleasure of playing. It comes highly recommended and I will be waiting excitedly for a return trip to the Lands of Dream.

22081731.review:
The Sea Will Claim Everything is a very detailed adventure game that focuses on story. Almost every object in TSWCE can be examined, giving you interesting descriptions. The game goes as far as giving each of the mushrooms their own little backstory. Reading these is always enjoyable, thanks to the great writing.

TSWCE is very nonlinear. There are two roadblocks near the beginning that restrict where you can go, but beyond those, you can do nearly everything in any order you want. There are a lot of objectives to accomplish, which can get overwhelming. Since the explorable area is quite large, it's sometimes difficult to find what you're looking for. The puzzles themselves are easy, so anyone should still be able to finish the game with enough patience.

The graphics are nice and colorful. You meet several imaginative characters along the way, all of which are well illustrated. The background music is atmospheric and relaxing.

TSWCE is one of the most underrated games ever made, in my opinion. If you'd like to explore a surreal world and enjoy story heavy adventure games, it's definitely worth playing.

22073384.review:
I knew about The Sea Will Claim Everything for some time but only now did I finally play it. Should have done it sooner.

TSWCE is a game full of whimsical charm. The Land of Dreams as a setting is a creative and engaging one filled with the strange and magical. There’s also obscene amounts of flavor text for things such as every book and mushroom in the game. The writing is filled with corny jokes and silliness that while it may not always hit is still really endearing. The game also has a really strong fairy tale/children’s story aesthetic and the music is great too. TSWCE is also a political fable, being very critical of the economic policies that led to the Great Recession of 2008 as well as reactionary ideologies in general. Philosophy is also a major part of TSWCE and the some of the game’s major themes are the dangers of ignorance, greed, and strict adherence to dogma and that one of the most important ways to make the world a better place is for people to be open to change and have an understanding and empathy for the people and world around them. This all done well and a major reason why is because the setting and characters have so much care put into them so that the message doesn’t envelop the narrative and instead works alongside it and they enhance each other.

Gameplaywise it’s more of a point and click game, the magic screen is your UI and most puzzles are more simple stuff such as item gathering, talking to people, and exploration. As the game tells you from the get-go it’s a bit of a slow paced game, but it’s still real engaging.

Overall TSWCE is a unique and  enthralling game with a lot of heart and a well-crafted message.

22070482.review:
One of my very favorite games. 

At first, it's simple. Click everything. Read, relax, and enjoy. Talk to every mushroom (they are pretty insightful). Soon the great writing and the wonderful visuals will make you a permanent visitor of the Lands of Dream. An amazing story if you're looking for a journey through beautiful imagined worlds.

22068697.review:
I never got to play the game despite having it from BitB. Now I decided to fix this and I am glad I did!

Incredible experience hidden beyond seemingly cute visuals. When you finish, you will think a lot about many ideas presented in the game. The game requires patience and sometimes you have to think outside the box. Apart from a few pixel hunting, the gameplay was quite smooth for me. No glitches either.

If you hate reading skip this game, otherwise I highly recommend it to everyone.

22067927.review:
Note, review based on the original version of this game

This game is part of a serie of game called 'land of dreams' by Jonas Kyratzes(he also worked on 'The Talos principle'), each game is basically exploring weird surreal world. The previous games are free games, but aren't necessary to be played in order to enjoy this one. Each screen looks like a well colored but simple children book pages, where every single element can be clicked for a description or a small joke or a weird anectdote. I you see a Library with 50 books in it, you can be sure that all 50 have something to say! It's not pixel hunting either : the main goal is usually quite easy to do. But the world is just fun to explore and the writing is superb!

It's mostly relax but very fun overall if you don't mind doing lots of reading!

22060738.review: I am amazed. TSWCE is pure glorious joy. Mine, when playing, and the creators', whose joy oozes out of every corner. The joy of a game full of personality, of invention, of depth. The joy of creation and of drama. There is so much content, both within (you see those rooms full of stuff in the screenshots? everything is clickable, up to every single different mushroom being described differently) and behind this game, and everything feels oh so great. Those felt-pen graphics? They're perfect. The music is fantastic. And the writing, well, is out of this world. I just started it and already am in love.

22044272.review: I first played this game years ago. Do not make the mistake (as I initially did) of judging it by the look of the screenshots. The look and feel of the game fits perfectly with the delighful writing and the varied setting. Even brief encounters with any of the numerous characters has meaning and little stories of their own. The non-linear exploration helps to keep things interesting and there is a journal that keeps track of all your tasks. This is one of those rare games where the player has the opportunity to at the end be a little wiser than when they started. The narrative subtly references situations you might find in the real world, but in a very indirect way so that the player is left to decide their own mind. As to the title of the game, I was initially sceptical, but it fits perfectly. I urge you to take a step into the land of dreams to see it for youself.

22035842.review:
In a world where steam sales push you to buy millions and millions of games that you'll never even finish anyway, where you try to rush every game so you can play the "other one", TSWCE propose you a deconditioning. Slow down my friend, here's a world you got to explore, take the time to read, understand, laugh, cry, feel awkward... I had to rethink the way I approached video games to be able to fully experience what the game and dev wanted me to experience.

I've been on steam for years and I never wrote a single review. You who are reading this right now, I invite you. Drop the Xbox controller, close that AAA game, stop that rage quitting platformer and enter a world where time stops and where you can marvel at everything.

Oh, and it's full of social science references.

22035395.review:
When I originally played The Sea Will Claim everything back in 2012, I really didn't know what to expect.  It seemed like it was going for some quirky, artsy charm (and it is), but the amount of depth and world building here is kind of incredible.  It's a game you can get lost in for hours.  And I lost my whole night to it - several nights, in fact!

The primary focus of the game is on exploring and examining things, and there is a surprisingly large number of scenes to traverse.  Every object has a unique description.  And while they're not all profound, you have to appreciate the effort it took to write that many unique descriptions of mushrooms.

Be warned: there is a tremendous amount of text to read, and the art is all static.  If that doesn't turn you off of the game, then jump right in.  Say "hi" to Bob the Spider for me.  Hopefully he won't devour you whole.

22027180.review:
The Sea Will Claim Everything is an impossibly charming adventure game with enough heart and quirk for five games. Look through a magic window in The Land of Dreams, a realm full of characters the likes of which you've never seen, and embark on a philosophical and emotional journey to save the Fortunate Isles from Lord Urizen.
I cannot speak highly enough about The Sea Will Claim Everything. This game will take you on a journey in ways that few others can, and the story it tells is unique and touching.
If you've ever enjoyed an adventure game, The Sea Will Claim Everything is something that you must experience.

22026519.review:
I played this game forever ago, back in the halcyon days of 2012 when it first came out, and I am so thrilled to see it finally make it to Steam in an expanded format. The Sea Will Claim Everything is terrific, just all around brilliant. Great writing, great jokes, great philosophizing. The best part is the way the game keeps blowing itself up over and over; every time you think you know what's going on, the camera pulls back, the scope gets bigger, more adventure appears. It's such a fun feeling of discovery. It was the first Lands of Dream game I tried, and I don't regret it for a second since it introduced me to the rest.

Shortly after I played The Sea Will Claim Everything, I remember reading the creators describe it as inspired by half forgotten shareware games on long lost demo discs, only The Sea Will Claim Everything actually has the rest of the game attached to it. That really stuck with me, because it's a perfect way to describe the game. The Sea Will Claim Everything is like all the adventure games I wanted to finish playing as a kid, but I finally get to explore the world beyond the end of demo screen.

Can't wait to see what's been tweaked and polished in this new version four years later. Welcome back.

22025749.review:
This game is really special, I really enjoyed and it's easy to recommend if you're interested in click and point games, literature, weird and funny things and different experiences.
It's one of the most overlooked games I've ever known of. Don't let this game pass under your radar.

22025501.review:
You know what I admire the most about [i]The Sea Will Claim Everything?[/i] That it makes you adapt to its own pace: slow, almost languid. There is no rush, the game says. Come, sit down, have something to eat. Let’s just talk and watch the world in its endless beauty for a while.


It’s an easy one to pigeonhole: a first-person, fixed-perspective point-and-click adventure game with a heavy emphasis on dialogue and some mechanically light but clever puzzling. Populated by weirdos. Childlike art, lots of words, copious amounts of deliberately groanworthy puns. Moderately long. There we go: the Urizen within us is satisfied.

And yet it’s more than the description of its moving parts. Perhaps most of all, it’s a game about reading cheerful nonsense while listening to achingly beautiful and soothing music; it’s silly and playful and aware of itself and aware of you. It’s a love letter to Greece as it exists in the imagination. It’s a game about the wonders of the world, about the awe and joy of being alive, at this point in time, in this place, for now and forever. But it’s also a game of profound sadness, the sense that something is ending and the future is uncertain and scary, but even if we one day look back and see that some of the stops along the way were bad, we’ll know the journey has been worth everything we had.

Constantly weaving between hilarity and melancholy and everything in between, wearing both its childish wonder and its world-weariness proudly on its sleeves, but in the end always joyful, even in the face of tragedy, that’s what TSWCE is like. Unhurried, contemplative, happy. A drinking white wine in the sun kind of game: a rare and beautiful animal.

But also very, very silly.


The game is part of the Lands of Dream cycle, but knowledge of the other stories is not at all required for understanding the plot. You know what, though? If you’re even moderately interested, give [url=http://landsofdream.net/games/the-fabulous-screech/]The Fabulous Screech[/url] a try. It’s a free, very short and beautiful game, and the Lands of Dream in a nutshell. And when you come back, [i]The Sea[/i] will still be here. And in the end, it will claim everything.

22025017.review:
This is my favorite videogame, and I've played quite a few. I'm glad it's finally on Steam.

The journey to the Lands of Dream is one you must take yourself: You have to live it, [i]be[/i] there, to understand. I recommend it to you, especially if you like point 'n' click adventures and slower-paced games. Take your time, explore, examine every nook and cranny, talk with all the lovable characters (which have actual depth, instead of being one-dimensional caricatures), and just enjoy the experience.

22021652.review:
This --this wonderful, verbose, touching, beautiful, silly, thought-provoking, vividly illustrated and hilarious portal to the Lands of Dream-- is most probably my favourite game of all time. And it comes with an absolutely excellent soundtrack. And mushrooms. And puns. And even Bob the Spider himself!

Oh, dear, you really really must play this one.

It might even make you a better person...

39049062.review: This game is a joy. Savor it like you would have savored a good fantasy novel when you were a kid (or kid at heart). If you've ever read and enjoyed Tolkein, C.S. Lewis, Lewis Carroll, Ursula Le Guin, Madeline L'Engle, L. Frank Baum, Suzette Haden Elgin, or Terry Pratchett, please play this game immediately. If you haven't, but you think reading a good fantasy novel is something you might enjoy, give it a shot anyway. If you don't like a lot of reading, this game might not be for you. But as of this review, it's two bucks, so you don't have much to lose. You might be surprised.

38984568.review:
Beautiful, funny, delightful point-and-click adventure! 

The artwork is simple yet charming and the dialogue, although at times a bit wordy is fantastic. The amount of detail in this game is astounding! Every item has a description, every book has a name (trust me, I clicked them all).

You can't go into this game with a deadline in mind. Get yourself a cup of tea and a blanket and dedicate yourself to appreciating this masterpiece. Go slow. Explore everything. Click every mushroom.

39573618.review:
I played this game with my Friend. I have not been able to get through a single point and click adventure game as an adult. I find myself easily distracted, and after a long day of work, I have little patience for figuring out puzzles, or reading large block of texts in a video game. But this game, with my Friend, I enjoyed. I found myself sad when there were no more problems to solve or large blocks of text to read  and   the game ended. 

Over two weeks, sitting in my room, huddled by the computer, reading the walls of text out loud to each other, we played this game. It has no voice acting, but make no mistake: the characters have voices. We took turns bringing them to life with our voices, and we would try on each other's voices and make new voices. We got pretty Fancy with it.  This review is not about how good our Fancy character voices were, although believe me, the warthogboy outside Darragh's voice was :fire emoji: :fire emoji: :fire emoji: Fancy. 

I lied, this review is about how good our character voices were. They were Good. They were so Good. Things got musical too! 10 stars.   

also good: The music (I downloaded the soundtrack on spotify!), the game's specific sense of humor, the music again, the inventory mouse, and the Truth of the characters and their problems- more than once, my Friend and i would stop reading and mutter something like "damn... that's some real sh*t right there...yeah." 

This game is political, but don't worry- it's the good politics.  

I can't be sure I would have had the patience to play this game on my own, and that's on me and my sh*tty brain, not the game. With my Friend, I am happy I played this game.

If you can find a Friend to play with, then 

a) You are very lucky 
and
b) I recommend The Sea Will Claim Everything.







also

c) our character voices were   v e r y  v e r y  G o o d
