40638501.review: An unbelievable point n click. The amount of time gone into the descriptions must have been massive. Great art, great music, big recommend!

40246718.review:
The Sea Will Claim Everything is a point and click game based on exploration and reading. In it, you explore the Fortunate Isles in Lands of Dream, a mysterious fantasy land taken over by Lord Urizen. The game revolves around helping the inhabitants of the islands with their problems, all while the game depicts the inevitable problems of authoritarianism and right-wing ideologies.

This game is a unique gem between point and click games, as it has some very distinct differences. There aren't really any puzzles in this game, it's quite wordy and there is an incredible amount of detail and thought put into the game, as every book in a library, every mushroom in a cave, every small detail has a unique description. Reading everything is quite time-consuming, yet to me it felt very rewarding as there are some brilliant jokes all around.

The game's story is a very political one, yet it didn't feel forced. Instead of having everything blatantly focus on politics, this game rather choose to place its attention on individual people and their lives. Even though the outlook is grim, there is a strong feeling of community within the various locations in the game. The story, for the most part, is also left in the background, leaving more space for exploration of the world and the characters in it. The small bits of story that appear here and there are brilliant and thought-provoking.

Artistically, this game is unlike anything you can find out there. The writing by Jonas Kyratzes is incredible and manages to present the different points and events of the game in a very natural flow. As for the graphics, everything is hand-drawn by Verena Kyratzes, who manages to give the game a one-of-a-kind presentation, capturing the feeling of Mediterranean lands and culture in a way I hadn't ever seen before. And the soundtrack is done by Chris Christodoulou, an incredibly talented greek musician who you may have heard of from indie titles such as Risk of Rain and Deadbolt.

This game somehow manages to be as philosophical and political as it is comfy and light-hearted. I have high hopes for this developer's next game, the Council of Crows, and I definitely recommend this game if it seems like your type of deal (though it is very niche).

40077157.review: When I bought this game, I was in the market for a good casual humor/fantasy game, or novel in the style of Brian Jacques (I was searching at both Indigo and Steam).  I had a desire to get lost in that detailed fantasy world and anthropomorphism that creates its own engaging, unique narrative with a nod to very human political and social matters.  Well Jonas, and the various beings of the Fortunate Isles, might be horrified to know that I selected this game over reading an actual book - and I think it was a good choice! Get ready to read in this point-and-click game, and don't let the graphics fool you, the language, humor, and story are sophisticated.  I found myself laughing out loud from the witty character banter, many MANY book titles (both real and custom), and descriptions of the scenerary, especially the mushrooms ("this is actually a muffin"!) By the end of the game (probably would have been 10 hours on the dot if I would have completed the last two achievements) I had the same sense of accomplishment that you get after reading a short novel, however, felt more bonded to the characters.  I was happy that Jonas had the foresight to allow the player the closure of going back at the end and saying bye to everyone! The detail and thoughtfulness of the game blew me away!

39847109.review:
Great point and click game by one of the writers behind The Talos Principle.

Don't let the simple graphics fool you, this game is really good. There is a lot of dialogue to read, but the interesting story makes it all worth it. The game is also much bigger than I thought at first, it took me almost 8 hours to complete.

If you like adventure games set in a fantastic world, philosophy, and point and click games, you should give it a try!
